I have only one issue with Emilys List. I fundamentally disagree that the gender of a candidate should have any impact on a choice to elect the person. I recall Barbara McClintock, the famous geneticist who inspired thousands of women scientists. She was going to be presented an award for her contributions to science and when she went to the award ceremony, she was informed that she was being recognized for being a great woman scientist, not a great scientist (which she absolutely was, her work on transposable elements was revolutionary (for anyone who cares... "jumping genes").) She left the conference and declined the award because she refused to accept the recognition conditioned on being a woman. You know what? I think she was absolutely right. She was a phenomenal scientist regardless of what her genitals looked like.      I think politicians should follow her example.

If you have a problem with a person getting elected just because of their gender, then you should understand the purpose of Emily's List. The absolute barrier that kept qualified women out but allowed inept men in has been removed. But, the systemic series of biases that make endorsement and election much easier for men remains. What has brought some progress are efforts undertaken with great intentionality to overcome those barriers and enable female an opportunity to make their case. Male privilege allows us to not recognize those barriers exist if it feels politically inconvenient to do so.

This issue is clear as mud; I've only had a couple basic readthroughs on the rules change recommendation, but I'm getting steadily a bit more clearer about it. On one level, there's an attempt to shift the nomination directly to the delegates, and to remove any influence that the presiding officer would have, which would be a high-level party member. They're worried the party will intervene and rig the process such that the delegates have no choice but to abandon both Trump and Cruz; this isn't an idle worry, but it's an unlikely political move, because the optics of it will come at an enormous cost. On the flip side, I think the party is legitimately worried that if you give the delegates too much power over the preceedings, it will create nationally-televised chaos and gridlock. I'd have to look at the minutiae of detail to have a better sense, but I think changing the rules this close to the convention removes the one certainty in an already bitterly-contested situation.

Use of the Oxford comma is stylistic, meaning that some style guides demand its use while others don’t. AP Style—the style guide that newspaper reporters adhere to—does not require the use of the Oxford comma. I think that snake oil Bob will prevail because this is more of an ethics issue than a straight up quid pro quo under criminal law. Until just recently the Governor of Virginia was free to accept personal gifts of unlimited value from people with business before the government (a new law limits gifts to $100 a year). Because there was no statutory prohibition on taking money or gifts, the jurors had to infer that the calls to state agencies were payback motivated by corrupt intent, as opposed to friendship. That required looking inside of the mind of the Governor to discern his feelings and true intentions, which is pretty much impossible in the absence of ancillary evidence.

You make an excellent point. If there is no applicable ethics law (and there should be), using DOJ and a criminal law approach does raise some serious due process issues. A potential defendant is entitled to know what the law requires him to refrain from doing.

Yes that's right. But the on and off target Nate uses to illustrate is not what you think it is. It is not on target for the final tally, its an instantaneous target for where a candidate needs to be right now. Hillary is 108% of her target. He is not where he should be today if he hopes to get nominated, while she has more than she needs at this stage of the race.      The math is simple. She needs 218 to win outright. He needs 1026. One thing to keep in mind about Trump's last round of strong finishes in the northeast is the relatively tiny proportion of voters who voted in those primaries.      According to 538, while participation in republican primaries among all voters has been averaging 20% in states so far, those in the northeast hovered around 5%. In part this is due to the lower proportion of Republicans in those states, but perhaps also because many middle of the road republicans simply sat out, not willing to stop Trump only to go on to a contested convention, yet not willing to support him outright.      If this is the case it shows just how factional of a candidate he is, and how weak of a general election candidate he would be. Winning by 60% sounds impressive, but not when it's out of 5% of registered voters.
